question_text: In Rococo art history, what French term originally described the decorative motif of pebbles, seashells, and cement used to ornament grottoes and fountains, which later gave the style its name?
In altarpiece construction, what is the technical term for the narrow horizontal row of small narrative scenes positioned directly below the main panel?
In tempera painting, what specific organic substance serves as the water-soluble binding agent in the most common classical form of the medium, known as egg tempera?
What was the name of the German Expressionist group founded in Dresden in 1905 by Ernst Ludwig Kirchner and three other artists, considered the founding organization of the movement?
Which German art historian and archaeologist, often called 'the father of archaeology,' wrote the influential texts that shaped the Neoclassical movement in both architecture and the visual arts?
Which French school of painters, active in the early 1830s, pioneered the practice of en plein air painting in natural light and strongly influenced the later Impressionist movement?
